Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Undergraduate Research In Astrophysics at the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory will continue its long-running summer REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) program. In addition to a 10-week summer research internship working with scientists at the Harvard/Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics (CfA), students will engage in numerous professional development activities, including computer tutorials, research-training seminars, and directed meetings with astrophysicists at all career stages. Students will also attend group discussions on the ethical conduct of research, graduate school life, admissions, available fellowships, and career opportunities after graduation. Since 1994, over half of the interns have been female, and a small but increasing number from underrepresented groups. During this renewed program greater emphasis will be placed on recruiting students from underrepresented groups as well as from colleges with limited resources for astrophysical research.

Each summer, ten students will spend ten weeks conducting leading-edge research with their mentors at CfA. Scientists at the CfA are involved in virtually every area of astrophysics and have access to a large number of modern scientific instruments, so students have a broad range of projects to choose from. The student research experience will be completed by a trip to the winter AAS meeting, where each intern will present a poster.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This document is the project outcomes report for the NSF-funded program entitled "REU Site: Undergraduate Research In Astrophysics at the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory,"which operated from May 2017 to July of 2019 in Cambridge, Massachusetts.


This REU site supported two cohorts of undergraduate interns, one each during the summers of 2017 and 2018.  Our students, who came from all over the country, were matched with research advisors at the Center for Astrophysics, and carried out real-world research projects during the 10-week terms of their internships.   The research topics were drawn from all science divisions of the Center for Astrophysics, and thus reflect a diverse range of subjects, ranging from theoreticalmodels of large-scale structure, and models of the chemistry of protoplanetary disks,to multiwavelength observations of galaxies, galaxy clusters, young stellar objects, and molecular cores. 


A major goal of our program is to strengthen the American scientific workforce through recruitment of women and underrepresented minorities into the Astrophysics field. We hosted a total of 20 students at our site.  Of those 20, 14 were women and 6 were men.  Eight (40%) were members of minority groups.  We were successful in our recruitment goal: 9 members of the 2017 cohort have committed to graduate school in astrophysics, and the 10th is working in science research.  All but two members of our 2018 cohort eligible for graduate school have committed to a graduate research institution, one of them has opted to pursue a teaching career.  Three members of our 2017 cohort, and two from the 2018 cohort, were awarded the Goldwater Scholarship after participating in our program.  In short, the indications are that our recruitment goals are continuing to be met.


Our program, now in its 25th year, implements a significant professional-development component, which includes weekly colloquia on a broad range of topics by CfA researchers, workshops on paper writing, graduate school life, the graduate school application process, non-academic careers, and other things.  Because the CfA hosts several other intern programs(including two others from NSF), our interns meet and interact daily with many other undergraduate researchers; there can be as many as 30-35 other summer interns present, making for a vibrant social community.  Our program benefits greatly from synergy with the allied internship programs by alternating responsibility and costs for hosting seminars and social events, such as the ice cream social that kicks off the summer.


Our program benefits the community in other ways, for example by providing relatively young PhD researchers, especially women, with opportunities to advise students and to present their research to a diverse audience in our weekly colloquia.  Almost all of our speakers are at an early stage in their careers; about half of them are women scientists.


A somewhat unusual element of our program is the writing instruction we provide our interns.  All interns are required to document their research with a manuscript written at a professional level.  That paper is reviewed by the program directors and the interns' advisors at several milestones during the summer.  This gives our students training in academic writing that they might otherwise never receive.  Our goal is to develop writing their writing proficiency so that later, when they enter graduate school, they are able to efficiently write up and publish their work; it is an aid to their later success.  As a bonus, we sometimes publish their summer project papers in the refereed literature.


In summary, the SAO NSF Astronomy REU site at the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory provides our interns with an intellectually and socially rewarding environment in which they engage in real-world astronomy research, and gives them a strong boost on their way to productive careers in scientific research.
